items.content_html:
Description

Added example for constructing a ReadableStream using Response object

Motivation

This a simple and concise way to construct a ReadableStream from a variety of sources. I find that it is easier to use than the actual constructor and, in my experience, most ReadableStream objects that you interact with are made this way.

Additional details

Already added at the bottom of the page here.
items.title: Update ReadableStream

items.content_html:
Description

Recently the Mozilla MDN team was talking to BrowserStack about updating our automated testing docs to update the BrowserStack content to reflect the new state of their products.

This PR:

  • Updates all the BrowserStack automation information to reflect up-to-date UI and workflow, to improve and simplify the examples, and to update the usage of the deprecated request node module to use axios instead. Note that we have not yet updated other product information.
  • Removes LambdaTest information. While we have nothing against LambdaTest, we decided that the information needed thinning out, as having too many example products is not helpful for beginners. It results in choice paralysis, confusing them in the process. It also requires a lot more maintenance. Future work will also decide if we remove or update other product coverage.

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Update BrowserStack browser testing docs

items.content_html:
HEVC WebCodecs encoding support has been enabled by default since Chrome 130
(https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5827845).

Safari/WebKit also already supported HEVC WebCodecs API last year, so add the document for HEVC.
items.title: Add HEVC for VideoDecoder/VideoEncoder

items.content_html:
Description

As of Firefox 132 (release October 29th) Enhanced Tracking Protection Strict mode will block all third-party cookies. Developers may still opt-into third-party cookies using CHIPS.

Motivation

The Firefox Privacy Team wants to update all relevant documentation regarding third-party cookie blocking for the Firefox 132 release.

The article should reflect the most recent Firefox (third-party) cookie behavior. Developers should know that CHIPS can be used to opt-into partitioned third-party cookie usage with Enhanced Tracking Protection Strict third-party cookie blocking.

Additional details

See https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1918037.

Since this is my private account I am adding my Mozilla mail in case further questions arise:
lschwarz@mozilla.com
items.title: FF132 Update third-party cookies article Firefox details (ETP Strict 3pc blocking)

items.content_html:
Description

Enhanced the documentation for the capture attribute by adding new examples and simplifying explanations for clarity.

Motivation

These changes improve the documentation for the capture attribute by providing clearer examples of its usage. This helps readers better understand how to implement the attribute effectively in their applications, enhancing user experience.

Additional details

For more context, refer to the MDN Web Docs on the capture attribute for detailed information.

Related issues and pull requests

No specific related issues or pull requests identified.
items.title: Enhance  attribute docs with new examples and clarity

items.content_html:
Description

PR closes #36213
items.title: pseudo class description

items.content_html:
FF132 supports fetchPriority in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1854077. This adds a release note.

Related docs work can be tracked in #36121.
items.title: FF132 Relnote fetchPriority supported
Minor: scroll module: add a related concept

items.content_html:
FF123 adds support for gl.unpackColorSpace and drawingBufferColorSpace(). This copies the docs from the WebGLRenderingContext to WebGL2RenderingContext.

Note that the docs story in WebGL is a bit confusing. WebGL2RenderingContext is built on top of WebGLRenderingContext and includes everything it has plus some additions (new stuff and new additions to the old stuff). But for docs mostly the second version does not duplicate the original - but there are some exceptions. I think we should duplicate everything because it makes things more sane and the sidebar makes more sense.

Anyway, given that there was some duplication I chose to copy these two as well.

This is part of #36112
items.title: FF132 Add webgl2rendering unpackColorSpace

items.content_html:
This should be merged after my fleet of typo fix PRs.

This PR splits our custom dictionaries by topic, making them easier to maintain and inspect. It could also allow for more granular options in the future, such as whether each one should provide suggestions, or whether they should be case-sensitive.

@OnkarRuikar @bsmth
items.title: Reorganize custom dictionaries, better spell checking infra

items.content_html:
I am fixing a lot of nits in content. The goal is to make our custom dictionaries as small as possible by eliminating things that could be better recognized as words. This not only helps with automation but helps with human readers too, especially those who may be slow to recognize words.

  • About half of them are code not properly capitalized.
  • There are some real typos.
  • Occasionally I have to refactor the wording a bit.
  • Where we are demonstrating real typos, I use inline cSpell:ignore to prevent it being ignored in other files.
items.title: Fix typos and pseudo-typos 13
